# Week 4

# 9/10: Byrd, Byrd, Byrd

Reminder: HW4 is due on Friday!

We'll start today by introducing first species counterpoint in three parts. We'll look briefly at how Renaissance musicians would have described the things that we call root-position and first-inversion triads. Then we'll study some sacred music by William Byrd, discussing his position as a Catholic composer in Tudor England. The motet "Civitas sancti tui," in particular, may be a useful point of reference for you as you work on Project 1. (Due next Monday.)

Presentation

  • First Species Counterpoint in three parts
  • Some background on Mr. Byrd
    • Galliarde to the third Pavian, Recording
  • Byrd, Mass for Four Voices, Kyrie (CP:62)
    • Annotated score, Recording
  • Byrd, "Civitas sancti tui" (CP:68)
    • Translation, Recording

Handout: First Species Three-part Guidelines

# 9/11: Drill

Today you'll do some analysis practice in Drill, studying another Palestrina mass movement.

  • Return HW3
  • Palestrina, Missa brevis, Kyrie
    • Translation, Recording

# 9/12: Text setting and "Word Painting"

Reminder: HW4 is due on Friday!

(And Project 1 is due on Monday.)

Today we'll look at a motet by Palestrina, focusing on how he sets poetic texts. We'll also study a Kyrie by Monteverdi. But first: we'll review the Modes briefly.

  • Mode Review
    • Handout from earlier
    • Zarlino on the modes
  • Palestrina, "Surge, amica mea" (motet)
    • Translation, Recording
  • Monteverdi, Messa da capella à 4, Kyrie

Presentation

Terms: Text-setting, word-painting, inversion, diminution, augmentation, retrograde

# 9/13: Drill

  • Practice first species counterpoint in three parts
  • Analysis of Lasso, "La nuict froide et sombre"
    • Translation, Recording

# 9/14: The Seconda Pratica

Today we'll discuss what happened when progressive composers at the end of the Renaissance started breaking the rules of counterpoint for expressive effects. We'll look at a famous example of this kind of rule-breaking in Monteverdi's madrigal "Cruda Amarilli". Then we'll discuss the critical reaction to that piece and some of the ways that Monteverdi and his supporters defended it. (Presentation)

  • HW4 is due before class
  • Some background on the Renaissance
  • Monteverdi, "Cruda Amarilli"
    • Score, Translation, Recording
  • The Artusi-Monteverdi Controversy
    • Extra reading (optional)

Terms: Madrigal, Prima pratica, Seconda pratica
